title: Łąka, Silesian Voivodeship
text:
Łąka (German "Lonkau") is a <a href="village">village</a> in the administrative district of <a href="Gmina%20Pszczyna">Gmina Pszczyna</a>, within <a href="Pszczyna%20County">Pszczyna County</a>, <a href="Silesian%20Voivodeship">Silesian Voivodeship</a>, in southern Poland. It lies approximately south-west of <a href="Pszczyna">Pszczyna</a> and south of the regional capital <a href="Katowice">Katowice</a>.
The village has a population of 2,690.
History.
In the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the area was part of the territory of the <a href="Vistulans">Vistulans</a> tribe, one of the <a href="Polish%20tribes">Polish tribes</a>. It became part of the emerging <a href="Duchy%20of%20Poland%20%28966%E2%80%931025%29">Polish state</a> in the 10th century. As a result of the fragmentation of Poland, it was part of the Polish <a href="Seniorate%20Province">Seniorate Province</a> and <a href="Duchy%20of%20Racib%C3%B3rz">Duchy of Racibórz</a>. The village was first mentioned in the 14th century.
Afterwards, the village passed under <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bohemia">Bohemian (Czech)</a> suzerainty, and in the 15th century, it became part of the newly formed <a href="Duchy%20of%20Pszczyna">Duchy of Pszczyna</a>. During the political upheaval caused by <a href="Matthias%20Corvinus">Matthias Corvinus</a> the duchy was overtaken in 1480 by <a href="Casimir%20II%2C%20Duke%20of%20Cieszyn">Casimir II, Duke of Cieszyn</a> from the <a href="Piast%20dynasty">Piast dynasty</a>, who sold it in 1517 to the Hungarian <a href="magnate">magnate</a>s of the <a href="Thurz%C3%B3">Thurzó</a> family, forming the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Pless">Pless</a> <a href="state%20country">state country</a>. In the accompanying sales document issued on 21 February 1517 the village was mentioned as "Luka". Along with the Kingdom of Bohemia in 1526, it became part of the <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a>. In the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Austrian%20Succession">War of the Austrian Succession</a> most of Silesia was conquered by the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a>, including the village, and in 1871 it became part of the <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a>. After <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, Poland regained independence, and following the subsequent Polish <a href="Silesian%20Uprisings">Silesian Uprisings</a> against Germany, the village was reintegrated with the reborn Polish state.
Transport.
The <a href="Voivodeship%20road">Voivodeship road</a> 939 runs through the village and <a href="National%20road%2081%20%28Poland%29">National road 1</a> runs nearby, east of the village.
Sports.
The local <a href="Association%20football">football</a> team is LKS Łąka. It competes in the lower leagues.
